_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES    

XTO Energy, Inc. (XTO) has a strong commitment to the protection of workers and the environment.

The Mustang Compressor Station site has an active safety program covering both

employees and contract workers. This program encompasses promotion of safe work practices to

prevent personal accidents, and incidents that would adversely affect the community. XTO

recognizes their commitment to accident prevention through continuing programs including

personnel training. Consideration is also given to safety in the design, installation, and operation of

natural gas production and gathering systems and modifications to the Site. The safety commitment

is also carried forth as evidenced by an aggressive maintenance program. Reasonable controls

have been implemented to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. In the unlikely

event that a release does occur, arrangements have been made within the local community to

provide response and control of any catastrophic releases. Passive mitigation, such as vents, is

present at the site to manage any overpressure conditions that may occur.



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The facility is located off FM 1776 with the closet town being Coyanosa located in Pecos

County Texas. Inherent with the operation of an oil and gathering and stabilization process, the

process stores regulated flammable substances above the threshold quantity. These flammable

substances are addressed throughout the RMP, and may include Ethane, Propane, Butane,

IsoButane, Pentane, and Isopentane, which are all components of the Natural Gas Liquids Product

(NGLP).

    

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC

PREVENTION STEPS    

XTO maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the

Site's processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for

key pr

ocess parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design

basis/configuration information. Employees at the Site are active in the development and

maintenance of up-to-date process safety information. Chemical-specific information, including

exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety

data sheets (SDSs). This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known

concerns. For specific operations areas, the Site has documented safety-related limits for specific

process parameters, such as temperature, level, and composition. The Site ensures that each

process is maintained within approved limits using process controls and monitoring instruments,

trained personnel, and automated shutdown systems.    

The Site also maintains technical documents that provide information about the design and

construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design

pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment. This information, in

combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing

inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and Site changes

to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

Operations at the Site have hazards that are managed to ensure continued safe operation. The

following is a description of existing safety features applicable to prevention of accidental releases of

regulated substances in the location.

    

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM    

The Site maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and

public safety, as well as to protect the environment. The program consists of procedures for

contacting responders for mitigation of a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of

a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures ad

dress

aspects of emergency response by outside experts and include proper first aid and medical

treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation,

notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and postincident

cleanup and any decontamination requirements. Employees receive appropriate training in

procedures necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties which includes

contacting trained responders. The emergency response program is updated when necessary based

on modifications made to Site processes or other facilities within the Site.

The overall emergency response program for the Site is coordinated with the Pecos County Local

Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). This coordination includes periodic meetings, which

include local emergency response officials, and local government officials. The Site contacts local

emergency responders annually with regard to the hazards of regulated substances at the Site.

XTO has implemented an Emergency Response Plan (ERP), elements of which overlap those of the

RMP. 



The ERP provides the following information:    

    

Procedures for informing the public and offsite emergency response officials of a release.

The individuals and groups contacted, the means by which they will be contacted, the time frame for

notification, and the information that will be provided is included in the ERP.

    

The proper procedures for first aid and medical treatment for employees, first responders, and

members of the public exposed to a release.    

    

Safety precautions for injured parties and detailed information for medical professionals

    

Information regarding who is likely responsible for providing appropriate treatment (e.g., an

employee, an employee with specialized training, or a medical professional).

    

Procedures for emergency response in the event of a release of a regulated substance, including

descriptions of actions to be t

aken by employees and other individuals onsite over the course of the

release event such as:    

    

Activation of alarm systems and interpretation of signals    

Safe evacuation, assembly, and return    

    

Selection of response strategies and incident command structure

    

Use of response equipment and other release mitigation activities

    

Post-release equipment and personnel cleanup and decontamination.

    

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY    

No changes are currently proposed for the Site. In the event a change is identified that would

improve safety, that change will be implemented upon management approval and directive.



Incident Investigation    

The Site has had no incidents, to date, that would require an accident investigation. However, there

is a system in place to investigate any incident that could result, or could reasonably result in, a

fire/explosion, flammable gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal

injury. The goal of an investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to

prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its

findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to

management for resolution. Corrective actions potentially taken in response to the investigation

team's findings and recommendations will be tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of

each finding or recommendation will be documented, and the investigation results reviewed with all

employees and contractors who could be affected by the findings.
